job_details.Functieomschrijving:
This is a new and structural position offered within the Department of Communication and Cognition at Tilburg University. It is funded by the Sectorplan Social Sciences and Humanities and partly associated with a recent NWO-KIC grant. The successful candidate will divide their time primarily between these two domains.

   In the Department of Communication and Cognition, we increasingly rely on computational methods, for example, to collect and analyze data, but also to develop new digital applications which can be used for research purposes. The research software engineer will offer support to researchers, PhD candidates and (research master) students by developing, maintaining, and/or customizing new and existing tools for research purposes. Since this is a new function, we anticipate that the successful candidate will help set-up a digital support structure for the department, maintaining an overview of available tools, and offering small-scale programming support for individual researchers.

   In the NWO-KIC project, we will develop a digital self-management platform that aims to help people with, for example, a history of depression to better monitor their own well-being, in order to prevent relapse. The platform to be developed will rest upon an existing experience sampling method (an app which asks participants repeatedly to briefly report on, for example, their thoughts, activities, and emotions on various moments during the day) and we will explore to what extent other sources of information can be integrated in this platform as well. The research software engineer will spend half of their time supporting the development and implementation of this platform.

   In short, the main tasks of the successful candidate will be offering computational support to researchers with their research, helping to manage the computational research infrastructure of the department, offering support in the education of technical skills, such as programming or (automated) data collection and annotation, and collaborating with researchers within the NWO-KIC project for the technical development of a self-management platform for people with severe mental illness.
job_details.full_text:
Research software engineer

This is a new and structural position offered within the Department of Communication and Cognition at Tilburg University. It is funded by the Sectorplan Social Sciences and Humanities and partly associated with a recent NWO-KIC grant. The successful candidate will divide their time primarily between these two domains.

   In the Department of Communication and Cognition, we increasingly rely on computational methods, for example, to collect and analyze data, but also to develop new digital applications which can be used for research purposes. The research software engineer will offer support to researchers, PhD candidates and (research master) students by developing, maintaining, and/or customizing new and existing tools for research purposes. Since this is a new function, we anticipate that the successful candidate will help set-up a digital support structure for the department, maintaining an overview of available tools, and offering small-scale programming support for individual researchers.

   In the NWO-KIC project, we will develop a digital self-management platform that aims to help people with, for example, a history of depression to better monitor their own well-being, in order to prevent relapse. The platform to be developed will rest upon an existing experience sampling method (an app which asks participants repeatedly to briefly report on, for example, their thoughts, activities, and emotions on various moments during the day) and we will explore to what extent other sources of information can be integrated in this platform as well. The research software engineer will spend half of their time supporting the development and implementation of this platform.

   In short, the main tasks of the successful candidate will be offering computational support to researchers with their research, helping to manage the computational research infrastructure of the department, offering support in the education of technical skills, such as programming or (automated) data collection and annotation, and collaborating with researchers within the NWO-KIC project for the technical development of a self-management platform for people with severe mental illness.

profile_classification.rationale: The job description focuses on supporting researchers with computational tools and developing a specific research platform, rather than building and deploying production-grade AI systems. While it involves programming and data handling, it lacks the core elements of ML model development, GenAI specialization, or MLOps typically found in ML or GenAI Engineer roles.

job_tasks.phrase: support to researchers, PhD candidates and (research master) students by developing, maintaining, and/or customizing new and existing tools for research purposes
job_tasks.justification: This phrase indicates understanding the needs of researchers (the 'business' in this academic context) and translating them into technical solutions (tools).

job_tasks.phrase: help set-up a digital support structure for the department, maintaining an overview of available tools, and offering small-scale programming support for individual researchers
job_tasks.justification: This shows an understanding of the department's needs for digital infrastructure and support, aligning technical offerings with user requirements.

job_tasks.phrase: develop a digital self-management platform that aims to help people with, for example, a history of depression to better monitor their own well-being, in order to prevent relapse
job_tasks.justification: This demonstrates understanding the 'business' goal of the NWO-KIC project, which is to create a platform for mental well-being monitoring and relapse prevention.

job_tasks.phrase: offering computational support to researchers with their research
job_tasks.justification: This directly addresses understanding the research needs and providing technical solutions.

job_tasks.phrase: collaborating with researchers within the NWO-KIC project for the technical development of a self-management platform for people with severe mental illness
job_tasks.justification: This highlights the need to understand the project's goals and work with researchers to achieve them.

job_tasks.phrase: computational methods, for example, to collect and analyze data
job_tasks.justification: This broadly refers to the processes involved in data collection and analysis, which are foundational to data engineering.
This explicitly mentions data collection and annotation, key aspects of data engineering.

job_tasks.phrase: existing experience sampling method (an app which asks participants repeatedly to briefly report on, for example, their thoughts, activities, and emotions on various moments during the day)
job_tasks.justification: This describes a data collection mechanism, implying the need to manage and process data from such a source.

job_tasks.phrase: explore to what extent other sources of information can be integrated in this platform as well
job_tasks.justification: This points towards data integration and pipeline development, core data engineering tasks.

job_tasks.phrase: develop new digital applications which can be used for research purposes
job_tasks.justification: While not explicitly ML modeling, developing applications for research often involves some form of data processing or algorithmic logic that can be considered a form of modeling in a broader sense.
Developing a platform, especially one that monitors well-being and prevents relapse, likely involves some form of data analysis or predictive logic, fitting a broad definition of modeling.

job_tasks.phrase: developing, maintaining, and/or customizing new and existing tools for research purposes
job_tasks.justification: This directly involves software development to create and manage research tools.

job_tasks.phrase: offering small-scale programming support for individual researchers
job_tasks.justification: This indicates performing programming tasks to assist researchers.
This is a core software development task, building a functional application.

job_tasks.phrase: supporting the development and implementation of this platform
job_tasks.justification: This involves the practical aspects of building and deploying the platform.

job_tasks.phrase: technical development of a self-management platform
job_tasks.justification: This explicitly states the role in the technical creation of the platform.

job_tasks.phrase: education of technical skills, such as programming
job_tasks.justification: This involves teaching programming, a fundamental software development skill.

job_tasks.phrase: help set-up a digital support structure for the department, maintaining an overview of available tools
job_tasks.justification: This relates to managing and maintaining the infrastructure and tools used for research, which has parallels to MLOps in terms of operational support.

job_tasks.phrase: helping to manage the computational research infrastructure of the department
job_tasks.justification: This involves managing the systems and tools researchers use, akin to infrastructure management in MLOps.

soft_skills.phrase: support to researchers, PhD candidates and (research master) students
soft_skills.justification: Implies interaction and support for various academic roles.

soft_skills.phrase: collaborating with researchers within the NWO-KIC project

soft_skills.justification: Suggests the need to work with and adapt to different tools.

soft_skills.phrase: help set-up a digital support structure
soft_skills.justification: Indicates a need to learn and adapt to establish new structures.
Implies a need to learn and then teach, requiring adaptability.

soft_skills.phrase: developing, maintaining, and/or customizing new and existing tools for research purposes
soft_skills.justification: Requires problem-solving to create, fix, and adapt tools.

soft_skills.phrase: offering small-scale programming support for individual researchers
soft_skills.justification: Involves addressing specific programming challenges for researchers.
Building a platform from scratch requires significant problem-solving.

soft_skills.phrase: explore to what extent other sources of information can be integrated
soft_skills.justification: This is an exploratory and problem-solving task related to data integration.
Suggests an opportunity to innovate and take ownership of a new role.

soft_skills.phrase: help set-up a digital support structure for the department
soft_skills.justification: Implies taking initiative and ownership to establish new infrastructure.
Taking ownership of providing support to individual researchers.
